title: Makerfarm i3v 10" frame clip for wire bundle from heat bed

description.text: I was inspired from this filament clip design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12516 to make this clip to hold the wire from my heat bed to the frame near the arduino board. I used a split flex tubing from Lowes to cover the wires from the heatbed. I added a slot in the top of the clip so I did not have to disconnect the wire from arduino board to route it thru the opening. I also added 4 slots in the clip to wire tie it in place. The round opening for the wire bundle is 16mm in diameter. I used a fill density of .2 & .2 layer height & it an hour to print.

title: Upright Braces for Mendel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm trying to help remove some of the hardware needed to build a Mendel. I think this might be a start.
It's rough working copy of some braces and end caps. The end caps have holes that bolts can be used instead of long threaded rods. Still needs some locking edge to keep the braces in the end caps tightly. 
It's 340mm from end to end. Each brace is 20mm wide with a 2.5mm thickness of each small brace arm. I tried to make all the brace arms square.

I wouldn't suggest printing it as-is. Please feel free to make changes.
It's saves as a Google Sketch Up file. I don't have any other 3D CAD programs. Can anyone suggest any good ones?

comments.text: I suggest to set it under stress with a tighened wire through it.

remixed_from.title: 15mm Camera rail adapter for DSLR rig

description.text:
I created this adapter to connect my camera to a mount that I printed from another user. This is a standard/universal size hotshoe to hotshoe mount in case your ever looking to connect two cameras or hotshoe sized holes together. It has tapered edges on one end for entry, and fits snug into my Nikon D5100. It should fit any standard hotshoe on a DSLR. One side is flat so the design Optimized for 3D printing.
It prints in about 15 minutes without any supports. I recommend 10%+ infill to support your expensive gear
It is plastic, use at your own risk. Enjoy1

Printed in black PLA
with a 10% infill
No support material needed This print is ready for use off of the build platform!

title: Undertable TV Remote Caddy, Storage for Six
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I needed room on my small round table that sits between chairs, as the various remotes, game controllers, and drinks were overwhelming it. This caddy is designed to mount under the table. It provides two primary remote controls spots with four other spots for less often used remotes. Its massive and will hold some of the largest remotes out there. The cutouts on the top are to fit around the tables various bits on the underside. If you find my designs useful, please help by donating.

This was designed to print without support, but a brim will help hold it to the table.  
This thing is big.  If you need to hold less remotes and build a less massive caddy, just slice off the ends to make it either a four remote caddy or even all the way down to just two.  
The mounting holes are only designed for four or six though, but 3M makes some double sided tape with 30lbs holding strength that works very well if you can't use screws.

author: FreeBeast

description.text:
A slightly more parametric version of the above thing. I needed a quick handle for a 5.5mm bit, and this turned out to work quite well. 
You can scale the bit holder and screw cap with a single parameter. To adjust the handle, you will still have to adapt a bit more to your needs. It has a few unparametric template objects to cut off the handle (for smaller build surfaces) and reshape the handle grip (to make it more comfortable). The scad file requires the stl files of the above thing.
Feel free to flattr this, the original thing, or any derivatives if it helped you like it helped me. I did.

I printed a copy of all three parts with full solidity, without raft. 
The screw connection did not work out well, so I resorted to the simple plumbers trick of joining the handle and bit holder with squeezed tape, making the cap obsolete. It works perfectly for me.

title: Ball In Cage Distorted
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This is what happens when you take an "engineered" design from Groboto and distort it in Sculptris, a free sculpting program from Pixologic. I'm still amazed at the very fluid process of creating (and distorting) a virtual thing and then getting a physical object at the end.

I used ReplicatorG on a MakerBot Replicator2 with the Replicator 2 slicing defaults and the following settings with white PLA from ProtoParadigm: Infill = 10%
Layer Height = 0.200

Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220 I used a raft with full support.

author: froetz

title: DroneBot Quadcopter Robot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is DRONEBOT! Its a 3D Printable quadcopter which is so incredibly tiny!
260mm motor shaft centre to motor shaft centre. If you want a complete RC FPV Drone then this is what youâ€™ll need. Though everything for a complete drone is pretty pricy some things such as the transmitter only need to be purchased once..the transmitter had something called model memory so you could have say 6 different models all with different settings and you just click the model that you programmed and named in a menu for the model that you want to fly. Also these batteries can be used on other models. Parts list:
X4) Brushless motors http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__5378__C1822_Micro_brushless_Outrunner_2100kv_14g_.html
X4) Speed Controllers http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__18002__HobbyKing_Red_Brick_10A_ESC.html
X4)Propellers http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__22753__5030_Propellers_Black_3xCW_and_3xCCW_6pcs_per_bag.html (you will break props in the learning process so buy as many sets as your budget allows)
X1) Flight Controller http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__22322__MultiWii_NanoWii_ATmega32U4_Micro_Flight_Controller_USB_GYRO_ACC.html
X5)Batteries http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__18847__Turnigy_800mAh_3S_30C_Lipo_Pack.html ( I recommend getting as many batteries as you can, I recommend at least 5 since that means you can fly over and over once the last pack is depleted you can add the next charged one and recharge the other)
X1) Transmitter http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__8992__Turnigy_9X_9Ch_Transmitter_w_Module_8ch_Receiver_Mode_2_v2_Firmware_.html (includes the receiver)
X2) Gold Connectors http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__66__2mm_Gold_Connectors_10_pairs_20pc_.html (very commonly used to connext motors to speed controllers, SOLDERING REQUIRED)
X1) FPV System http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__20672__Fat_Shark_Predator_RTF_FPV_Headset_System_w_Camera_and_5_8G_TX.html (Includes all fpv equipment)
X1)Cloverleaf Antennas http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__27750__5_8GHz_Circular_Polarized_spiroNet_Antenna.html (Highly recommended over the standard antennas that come with the FPV System as they improve range..over a Mile..) It is Developed as my entry into a Develop3Ds printer competition :) Thank you Not For Commercial Use
http://www.youtube.com/user/FlyHighRC386?feature=mhee please check out my blog on 3D printing http://3printerandd.blogspot.co.uk/
You will need to print off four of the motor arms which are the long pieces :)

comments.text: hi. i just printed the body part of your design and it came out great, i scaled it up to 145% 1 shell with 100% fill, layer height .15. printed with abs in gray at 220 extruder 110 bed using abs slurry over kapton tape on a flashforge dreamer. it took 32 meters and 12 hours to print. support was used and printed it flat and face up. fits perfectly on the printer bed and to my surprise the four mounting posts now fit a kk2 flight controller perfectly. the leg openings are 8mm. already did a test print of a leg in low quality and it printed well at 2 shell and 15%fill. straight as an arrow no warping visible. strong enough to test fly but not crash resistant. initially not a good fit between the two and some sanding is needed. the body top is printing right now. i hope it comes out ok with no supports and 1 shell w/100% fill. 5hr and 10mts of filament. thanks so much for this sweet little robot drone. i need help posting photos and choosing the components. open to suggestions.

title: Melting Ball in Cage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Here's another variation (the last?) on the ball in cage design. I used Groboto for the basic model, distorted it in Sculptris and then added the ball in Cheetah3D. 
The first time I printed this, I had the "puddle" horizontal but the grain in the cage looked odd since it printed it at an angle. For this version, I printed it with the cage vertical and the puddle at an angle. The grain came out fine then.

I used ReplicatorG on a MakerBot Replicator2 with the Replicator 2 slicing defaults and the following settings with white PLA from ProtoParadigm: Infill = 10%
Layer Height = 0.200

Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220 I used a raft with full support.

title: Filament guide bracket & spacer - Replicator dual

description.text: This filament guide replaces the original clips on a Replicator dual (mine is a CTC model based on the FlashForge design). Its purpose is to feed the filament from the centre of the reel to help avoid tangles and the reel jamming against the side of the Replicator. You may also find the accompanying spacer useful to keep the reel away from the side of the machine.

Print with 50% infill or more for strength. The filament guide tube should be a snug fit in the cup of this bracket but you may need to vary the size slightly according to your machine. I've included the FreeCAD source to allow you to do so easily.

description.text: Snap this onto your Printrbot 1.75mm filament spool to save yourself the trouble of taping the end when not in use, or risking your spool uncoiling itself.  This may work with other brands of filament if they use the same or similar spool design.

Printed solid.  To attach the clip to your spool, rotate it 90 degrees from its final position, such that the opening on the spool clip lines up with the outer lip on the spool, the roll it into place. It should snap nicely.  Next, snap the end of your filament into the filament clip and you're good to go.

This is an experimental magnetic coil to test the theories of Vortex Based Math. The original file was almost impossible to print given the extreme overhangs, so I created two halves. This way there will be no overhangs, special thanks to Chris Cecil for the tip!

I'm still experimenting with the print settings, I will update my progress later. The final construction will be when the two halves are glued together. Then take conductive metallic paint to fill in the individual nested vorticies. Most experimental electromagnetic coils vary the number of windings, angle, etc. This prototype will have a varying conductive path to hopefully increase the electromagnetic implosion effect.

title: Mini Drill Press for PCB Drill

description.text:
This is my miniature Drill press. I made it to drill holes in PCBs. The brackets have a inside diameter of 24mm. Be free to read the instructions :) Inspired by this project on Thingiverse
(mine is a total redesign) Drill is from Ebay here
Sadly, the drill chuck could be better.

Part List: 6x M3x12
6x M3 Nut
About 320mm M6 threaded rod (70mm + 2*125mm)
4x M6 nut
2x M6 washer
wooden base 125x60x18mm
24mm diameter drill Motor (Ebay) Instructions

  • Print the parts out. Let them cool before you remove them, because you don't want to bend something (especially the slider).

    • Be sure the parts are completely cool, because if they are hot, they will shrink a bit. Rasp the slider crosswise on a sheet of sandpaper until it fits the base perfectly. The sandpaper should lie on a flat surface. I only sanded the surface width the gear rack. I attached the gear width superglue to the threaded rod. Same thing width the lever.

comments.text: As I can see, I need a drill press to make holes in the wood ? I just wanted to make one because I don't have one.

comments.text: Very nice design and simple! I was forced to adapt the bracket to a 34mm diameter one because my drill has a 35mm diameter, I will try to post the design to add to the collection if possible. I used Freecad to make the new bracket and forgot to drill holes to the bracket opening for a screw but as it turned out it was not really needed the secret is to make the bracket 1mm smaller than your actual drill diameter and it snugs perfectly well without any screw.

This is my 3D interpretation of Professor Farnsworth of Futurama. Print him to our space and time!  
I would love to see your prints, post them!

Farnsworth-E-Fin is a shell mesh with generated support in meshmixer and additional pillars have been added.
The software of my printer generated even more support so I can't tell if it works out with every printer.
To print him in a 12x12x12cm printer he has to be rotated 45 degrees. A part of the neck had to be cut off to lay him on the back of his head. The missing part can be printed seperately and then glued on.
The glasses are seperate. To get a better transparency the "sidewards" version is recommended but it might require generated support.
The "downwards" should work good in any case but a raft is strongly recommended since the temples are very thin. Alternatives:
Farnsworth-solid-NoSupport is without support, solid and not split.
Farnsworth-shell-NoSupport is without support, a shell and split.
Farnsworth-SourceFull-Solid is the whole model together, solid and seperated in the .obj (glasses and temples need to be thinner when printed seperately)

  • Please show a pic of your print, I'm curious.

  • Do not distribute the files anywhere and do not sell any prints made with these files!
    • Bests,
    David Hagemann
    @tocogamescom

This OpenSCAD module allows you to insert hinges into your object that print vertically, fully assembled and with no support material to remove. It represents the negative space of the hinge. Use the OpenSCAD difference() function to remove the negative space from your object. Small internal supports inside each hinge break and allow the hinge to move freely. Print the example hinges or import the OpenSCAD file into your project.

This is a cap for the Kuretake Waterbrush Petit that allows you to transport it with water inside,so you don't have to carry along the bottle of water that comes with it. With this small addition it is now the most portable waterbrush I have been able to find, and fits quite nicely in an Altoids-sized tin.

I printed the model in the pictures on a Makerbot Replicator II (flip the model to flat side down for printing). It's meant to come off just a tiny bit more easily than the brush comes out since you'll probably take them off in that order. Note: If you squeeze the brush hard while the cap is on, water will still come out the edges, so I wouldn't store it somewhere it's going to be compressed. I bought the specific waterbrush from JetPens: http://www.jetpens.com/Kuretake-Waterbrush-Petit-Set/pd/2674

description.text:
My first Thingiverse design is a Metroid/Tron mashup for plotting on spheres! Want to see a 15:1 timelapse of the blue ball being made? Of course you do!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UwzBYi5POJA Mostly copied from the video's description: The style worked very well for learning some new features in Inkscape! Most notably grid-snapping and tiled cloning (tessellations). :) Design and prototyping was done in one night, with most of the prototype balls only taking a minute or so to plot because they were done as outlines only. The final 2 balls took about 11 minutes each due to the large fills. The timelapse was taken at 1 photo per second, and played back at 15 fps. Unfortunately, this 15:1 time scale is basically as low as my phone can go while producing a decent movie. :P BONUS! If you look closely, you can see a small wake behind the pen where the ink is drying! BONUS! It's ridiculously tempting to even take the current design and plot it onto one of those motorized balls that randomly roll around! I can't seem to find a link to a simple version, but this pool-toy displays the basic idea:
http://www.amazon.com/Swimways-Crazy-Chase-Dive-Ball/dp/B0036FTLXI BONUS! I'm friendly! Comments are super-welcome! :D

• Download a copy of Inkscape! (NOTE: This program is awesome, so even if you don't want to own one of the coolest morph balls in town, you should get it and level up your computer!)
    http://inkscape.org/download/

  • Double-check and make sure you have at least version 2.1.4 of the Egg-Bot Inkscape extension! This is very important, because without the tiled-clone bug fix that version includes, the bottom row of the design will wind up being plotted right on top of the top row.
    http://wiki.evilmadscience.com/Installing_software/

  • Find something that makes awesome stepper motor sounds while doing stuff to spheres! Don't have one of these awesome devices yet? An Egg-Bot is a good place to start!
    http://egg-bot.com/

  • Get your hands on something round and a fine-tip marker!
    So far I've luck with these products:
    White balls! http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001RFRZ46
    Colored balls! http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004B7NWKI
    Sharpies! http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00006IFI7

  • Load one of the files, use the Egg-Bot extension, and then imitate your plotter for about 11 minutes!
    (Beeee! Errrrr! WREEEEE! Wran-wran-wran-wran.)
    • NOTE! The current hatching density was chosen for a 40mm ping pong ball with an ultra-fine tip sharpie. When using a grapefruit and chocolate frosting, it may be necessary to change the hatch's pitch! NOTE! I found that if you inset a hatching path by a few pixels, you can get much sharper looking edges on your objects! Related, I unfortunately can't find a way to hatch a clone and keep the original as an outline. shrug NOTE! If you're new to using tiled cloning in Inkscape (I certainly was!), here's a handy tutorial that steps through cloning a group and using the "Enter Group" feature to make changes to the group while it's still mirrored. It's super effective!
    http://simarilius.wordpress.com/2006/08/26/mirror-mirror-on-the-wall/ NOTE! Have fun!

comments.author: linuxwrangler

comments.text: FWIW, SVG itself supports the clones changing as you change that being cloned.  A clone is literally a reference (link) to the "master" with a transform applied (e.g., move this clone over here, thank you). So, any change to the master necessarily changes the clones since the clones are not actual copies but are instead symbolic links (in the UNIX file system sense).  And, the clone is of the referenced object and its children in the XML tree.  So, in SVG you'd group the object and its inset fill and clone the group.  Net, net, this is solely an Inkscape limitation.  (And perhaps a non-trivial one to fix; I've avoided looking too hard at the Inkscape sources.)

Sharing is caring, but sometimes there's a beer you'd rather keep for yourself. This customizable bottle lock will keep your beer safe. After coming across JON-A-TRON's Beer Bottle Lock (http://www.instructables.com/id/Beer-Bottle-Lock/), I was inspired to create my own. This design prints completely assembled and without any support material to remove. You can customize the text on the top face with the latest beta version of OpenSCAD. I'm using these little padlocks (http://www.masterlock.com/personal-use/product/121T) to keep my brews safe, but any small lock with about a 11mm (7/16in) diameter shackle should work fine. These print well on my Replicator 2 with .2mm layer height and 20% infill.
Bottle lock may not be effective when used with twist-off bottle caps.
Just print and use a small padlock to keep your beer safe. Any small lock with about a 11mm (7/16in) diameter shackle should work fine. I printed mine on a Replicator 2 with 2mm layer height and 20%.

This little chameleon clips onto your monitor, laptop screen, pencil, printer, mouse cord -- or just about anywhere else (as shown here, perched atop of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19104). 2016/1/25 Update: A new "V3" version with stronger limbs, built-in support and repaired geometry has been added. If you had difficulty removing supports without breaking the front legs on the other version, try this one! Print with 4 shells for strength. 2016/11/22 Update: V3 has been confirmed to work exceptionally well with semi-flex filament. I used raft (probably not necessary) and printed at slow speed. A version printed at 125% size grips a pencil very well. 2016/12/9 Update: The No Support version has been confirmed to print well at 50% or 60% size with raft (I used a helper disk instead) and no support. It hangs onto a piece of 1.75 mm filament, or a twig or wire with similar diameter. This version is confirmed to print well on a Tiko printer with default settings.

title: Shower Hook add-on for Shower Rack

description.text:
This shower hook is meant to extend the capabilities of your existing shower rack rather than stick to the wall or hang from the shower door.  
Please look at the 2nd picture to determine if your shower rack has horizontal bars that are suitable for the clamping mechanism. If not, this design won't work for you.

Print as-is with the settings of your choice. The only requirement is that Supports must be ON. I used MakerBot Desktop's PLA LOW Resolution (Fastest) setting:
.3mm layer height
10% infill
Supports: ON
Rafts: OFF
(and I like to heat my build plate to 40C)

Dimensions of the mechanism:
The mechanism can fit between any two vertical bars that are anywhere between 10mm to 27.5mm apart from each other.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

I printed it on both Leaprog Creatr (0.35mm nozzle) and Prusa i3 (0.3mm nozzle) printers with good results using following setings: Layer Height - 0.25mm

author: Pazinho

title: 19th Century Bronze Statue of Liberty Model

description.text:
This is a larger version of the Thiébaut Frères bronze model specially commissioned by Frédéric-Auguste Bartholdi.   
Bronze models like this one are eagerly sought by collectors as there were so few made. Bartholdi retained the copyright for casting copies of his working model of the Statue of Liberty in bronze and would only occasionally exercise it. Besides the one meter terra-cotta models sold to raise funds for the construction of Liberty in France, the bronzes cast by Thiébaut Frères are considered among the finest small-scale representations of Bartholdi's vision of Liberty. A copy of a one meter example of their work is on display at the Statue of Liberty Exhibit on Liberty Island.   
This example of the Statue of Liberty has lost its rays from the crown at some point in the past century and the right arm and torch are slightly bent inwards (probably from a fall) but the overall appearance is still appealing.   
I'm still tweaking the fine art of photographing dark, shiny bronze sculptures so Photoscan can capture more detail. This recreation is somewhat low in detail, but that is more my fault. If anyone wants to take a try at cleaning up the details and maybe attempting a little straightening out of the right arm and replacing the missing rays, by all means, be my guest!

author: KingWin33

title: Camp Susque (Trout Run, PA) Elevation Model

description.text:
The 46002160PAN tile from the 3.2 ft DEM from PASDA. Tiles from the LiDAR survey are 10,000 ft square. This 3D model is natively 127mm (aka 5") square. Area around Camp Susque, including Rattlesnake Mountain and Lookout Mountain. DEM Source: http://maps.psiee.psu.edu/ImageryNavigator/ My process for creating STL:
-Import GeoTIFF DEM into QGIS (http://www.qgis.org/)
-Convert to rendered GeoTIFF (see this tutorial http://maps.cga.harvard.edu/qgis/wkshop/export_GeoTiff.php)
-Import into Blender as plane (http://www.blender.org)
-Subdivide Plane several times (W)
-Apply sub-surface division modifier
-Apply GeoTIFF texture as Displacement modifier (use Extend image mapping)
-Add 1.0 Mean Crease to perimeter edges
-Apply sub-surface division then displacement modifiers to mesh
-Scale mesh object based on map size / height
-Edit mesh, select all, extrude down in Z
-Scale lower mesh to flat plane (S, Z, 0)
-Export as STL
-Done!

author: malbert

description.text: basic clips for plexiglass sides

A mount for attaching 3 LEDs to the Printrbot Metal Simple to provide light during a print so you an see the process clearly. I was sick of shining a torch on the print when checking it out, so I designed this. The mount clips easily onto the z probe, no screws/fancy alterations required. Other required components
  • 3 white LEDs
  • a suitable resistor
  • wires to power the LEDs

• Print the mount.
  • I used a small stripboard section to mount the LEDs. I simply put 3 LEDs in parallel, and limited the current with an 100 ohm resistor. The mounting holes are designed with the stripboard hole spacings. I added a header pin to allow connecting power to it.
  • Put the PCB onto the mount. The LEDs had a perfect fit for me, and are held in place by friction.
  • Clip the mount onto the z probe.
  • Connect a power source to the LEDs. I used the +5v and ground pins on the EXP1 header of the printrboard.

Proof, if any were needed that the pen is mightier than the sword once more. A highly symbolic item, being both practically supportive of the pen and artist as well as symbolicly so.  
A lovely looking print, useful and attractive in white or whatever colour you like.  
Suggest 1 perimeter and 15% infill will give great results and be fast, approx 4 hr print.  
Peace.
Its a small Quadcopter you can fly inside and not break stuff. The Props have guards to protect your walls and all electronics are protected inside the case.
I will update with instructions once I get it flying. And put on the BOM

description.text: I found a nice little 5mm LED on Amazon that plugged into my 4pin-molex connectors on the power supply I use to run my bot and wanted a place to mount the bright little bulb. This model is that solution. I found that the official fan shroud that Printrbot supplied was really pretty messy and just wouldn't slice with any settings I used. I went in and rebuilt the shroud (I am no fan shroud guru, I probably messed something up) adding a location for my new LED. I built in support for the LED holder, it printed fine on my bot without any other supports at .2mm layer heights and a 90% fill. I drilled the holes out a bit to make the install run a little smoother. I used the hole pattern and outside shape and threw the rest away. Original can be found here http://printrbot.com/project/simple-metal/

title: Flattened and CUTTABLE "Castle Under Attack" - Original laser cut model by Andrea Garuti

description.text:
This is a disassembled and flattened version of Castle Under Attack by Andrea Garuti, suitable for laser cutting.
Original CAD files here
http://grabcad.com/library/the-castle-under-attack Edits: (All old files will stay available, but you only need to grab the newest one)
Rev1 01-11-2015: Tebuchet had wrong size on some bucket pieces and upright holes, catapult2 had catapult1's top beam.

This is a hand-disassembled and flattened version of the astounding "Castle Under Attack" model by Andrea Garuti. Andrea's model was the grand prize winner of the GrabCAD/SolidSmack laser cut toy contest.
http://blog.ponoko.com/2013/05/02/awesome-laser-cut-castle-under-attack-features-working-catapult-trebuchet/ His work is so awesome, and it's so generous that he open-sourced his model files that I just HAD to generate a flattened, cuttable version for the masses. The original source file is an assembled version of the 1000+ piece 3D scene and is not cuttable. These files are hand-disassembled, snapped to x-axis, and flattened (2D projection) in Rhino to laser-cuttable pieces. I am 99.9% sure there are no overlapping lines or other cut-killers, but some of the 30mm circles (wheels) rendered oblong, so further cleanup of the files will take place as time goes on. So far, I have cut a couple of the siege weapons with good success. I will upload pics soon. If anyone wants the disassembled but unflattened IGS files, or is able to contribute to this project, please message me.

comments.text:
I've cut all parts up till now (except for the town houses), most of the things went fine, however I had to adjust for some minor mistakes in the design. (Mainly on the corner tower)
Has somebody build the entrance gateway? I'm unsure on how all the parts fit together.
Can you place the 3D file online in a STEP? or other format?
I'll place my version online once I finished assembling, I've outlined it on a 60x30 cut area, in 31 plates of 6mm thick. This meant I had to split up the base plate of the entrance gateway and the baseplate of the big tower, this has the advantage of easier storage as a side effect.

title: Electronics Sled Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an electronics sled designed for holding small rectangular electronics such as the Jolly Roger Altimeter or the Sonic Beacon to medium and high powered rockets. Sled will attach to the bottom of a nose cone with 3in diameter or larger, after slits are cut.  
This is the first prototype, and future updates will be made based on feedback.

I started by taking measurements of some of the smaller commercially available electronics for ameateru rocketry. There are many commercial options for attaching, mostly with laser cut, or prebuilt compartments and baffles which attach to the shock cord some way. I wanted something I could easily attach in seconds that would keep my equipment secure, while still allowing for modularity, and transitioning between different rockets.

description.text: I highly recommend using the most current version of this design, found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:243278

For a very nerdy Valentine's Day, I give you heart gears. This was inspired by Greg Frost's Broken Heart http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4683, but it fits in the palm of your hand and can be twisted like some kind of worry ball. It makes use of the heart shape from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6190, the MCAD involute bevel gear script from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575, and nophead's polyhole script for making properly dimensioned tap holes http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6118. UPDATE: If you lack a 3D printer, you can now buy these from CarryTheWhat at http://www.etsy.com/shop/CarryTheWhat. I was daunted by the complexity of Greg's design, so this one is much simpler, having fewer gears, and a much simpler attachment design (simply thread the bolts into tight plastic holes). It also uses a smooth heart shape and is made for the hand instead of the desk.

Each gear is unique, so print one of each (gears 5 and 7 are so similar, they can probably be interchanged).  Skeinforge can be a pain, but to get around one bug I found, uncheck "infill in direction of bridges" in Carve.  The one pictured was printed on a TOM.  
For assembly, I recommend screwing each gear tightly into the center block so it can't turn and place each gear so they are smooth and continuous.  The complete stl file is for assembly reference.  Once they're all in place, loosen each screw a turn or two until the gears spin freely.  Give to loved one.
The OpenSCAD file is fully parametric, so feel free to adjust to your heart's content.  It's designed for M3 screws right now, but that's an easily adjustable element.

comments.text: If your screws come loose, then the center holes may be too large or perhaps the gear holes are too small.  You can adjust them in OpenSCAD, but it's kind of a pain.  Sometimes it's easier to drill out the holes a little, and perhaps even use slightly larger screws.  You should have to tap them pretty forcefully into the center in order for them to stay firm.

comments.text: It's easier to understand once you have the pieces in hand.  I usually start with gears 1 and 6, because it's pretty clear how to align them by symmetry.  Then work your way around, making sure that where each new gear meshes, the surface is continuous.  I'll admit, it's a bit of a puzzle in its own right.

I liked the original idea of eveinhoffer and the 3D printable remix of thefear. However, the hole pattern in the coaster was not good for my pints and mugs. They were a little wobbly as there was small contact area in the middle.  
I took the dxf file from eveinhoffer's thing and modified it so that there are five same sized holes instead of four smaller and two larger holes. I scaled the coaster to suit my needs. As a bonus I made a lighter holder for the coasters.  
On the left in the image is the 96mm model and on the right the 119mm model.

I used 10% or 15% infill and they turned out pretty okay.  
The coaster holder is not properly tested so please comment if you try to print it!

Small 4 hole glue stick holder for the thinner glue sticks, the ones i measured were Elmers Disappearing Purple. The radius of the glue sticks I used were 20mm the hole is set to 21mm so it will be a semi-loose fit This thing is a better glue stick holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1178817

description.text: I needed a headset hook for my shelf - so why not simply printing one... Looking on Thingivers I found some more or less simple shelf hooks. But I wanted a more eye catching one, like Tosh Headphone holder. I have used the Impallari fonts Dosis and Lobster to generate the Text with Inkscape and extruded it with OpenSCAD. As this thing mainly benefits from the used fonts, which are released under Open Font License. So I am releasing this thing now under GPL license. Many thanks for the great work! Update Version 1.1: new parameter for wedge, bugfixes regarding OpenSCAD version of Customizer

You need two STL files, the one with the extracted text and the proper clamp for your shelf. TOP means pluged from top. Normaly you need the FRONT version. After printing you can simply snap the two parts together. I have already generated clamps for shelf thickness from 15mm up to 35mm. If you need a thinner or thicker one, use the customizer the create a matching clamp for your shelf. I used this setting for printing:
layer height = 0.3mm
wallthick = 1.5
infill = 40% IMPORTANT! If using CURA for slicing:
use 1mm wallthick setting for printing the bracket. Otherwise there will be no infill and you will get a limpsy bracket.

title: Sewing Thread Carousel in CD Spindle

description.text:
My daughter asked me if I had some idea how to store the many sewing thread spools and corresponding machine bobbins which started to accumulate since she got her new sewing machine. Fortunately I never threw away my empty CD/DVD spindles, always thinking that "some day" I will find something useful to do with them... So this little project builds a carousel for storing sewing thread spools inside an empty 50-CD/DVD spindle. :) The carousel consists of a round base plate for two concentric rings of spools and the corresponding number of spears onto which the thread spools are stuck. The spears are mounted on the base plate by sliding them into the corresponding rails. The top of the spears is hollow and acts as a compressible clamp for retaining a machine bobbin for the lower thread of the same color as the main spool on this spear. Given that the clamp need to have some flexibility, ABS is the material of choice for this project. The SCAD source is fully parametrized, so it can easily be adapted to special needs. In addition to the basic construction modules, specific modules are provided for some useful configurations, this include four carousels for
  • 14+7=21 small spools with diameters up to 22mm
  • 14 small spools on the outer ring plus 5 large spools with diameters up to 30mm on the inner ring
  • 12+6=18 medium spools of diameters up to 25mm
  • 10+5=15 large spools with diameters up to 30mm
    • For these configurations, ready-to-print STL files for the base plate are provided. As the same spears are used for all carousels, you just need to print the required total number of spears (plus maybe 2 or 3 spares) by combining the provides STL files for 1, 2, 5 and 10 spears. Note that the normal spears assume that the inner diameter of the sewing thread spool is at least 6.5mm. The heads of the normal spears can accommodate a machine bobbin with an inner diameter of 6mm (1/4"). For spools with inner diameters smaller than 6.5mm, you can used the narrow version of the spears. Note that the normal and the narrow spears have the same sliding rail, so they can be mixed on the same base plate.

For this project you'll need an empty 50-disc CD or DVD spindle including it's transparent plastic cover.  Print the desired carousel base plate plus the required number of spears.  Attach the spears to the base plate by pushing them into the rails on the base plate.  They should fit firmly, so a little force is needed to push them into place.  
I printed the plastic parts from 3mm ABS filament on my DIY Prusa i3, using a 0.4mm nozzle with 0.56mm extrusion width and 0.25 layer height. I print on a clear mirror without Kapton tape, but thoroughly cleaned with acetone first and then with double concentrated lemon juice.

Here's a board game called Corners. You can play it with a chess board and any kind of counters, or you can print it using the designs I created. This is a 2 player game which is great fun to play, really easy to learn and takes only 10-20 minutes to play through it. Here's how you play: Arrange the counters in a 4x3 rectangle in opposite corners of the board. Each person then takes it in turn to move their counters around the board, with the simple objective: move your pieces from where they are at the start to where the opponents pieces are. You may move only 1 square at a time, however not diagonally. You can only move once per turn, and can jump over pieces if that is possible. You can also combo-jump, where you jump over one piece and after landing, jump over another one, with the same counter. (You can only do this if the pieces allow you to! you cannot jump over more than 1 counter at once, and you cannot move in between jumps. A combo jump counts as one move). Continue to take turns until either player fills the other players starting square. The person first to do this wins the game. I've created and uploaded a series of images of example gameplay for the first 10 turns, so if you're unsure about jumping, refer to that. Please note that in the gif, the green side went first. When printing, no supports are needed. 2 sets of counters are needed, preferably in different colours! Have fun!
~ Michael

3D print the board, and two sets of counters all in different colours. If you only have one colour, feel free to create your own counters with shapes to determine them rather than colours, or use chess pieces / paper counters / similar.  
You can use a normal chess board to play this game.

title: K8200 Auto bed leveling with ballograf pen

description.text: I needed an auto bed leveling for my K8200 printer. Found some but most of them uses a 9g servo that places a micro switch on the bed. The problem with that is that the angel on the servo can't be exact the same every time. So I made another design based on "agence_akira" high precision probe http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:490024 But some lack of materials generated a complete new desing using stuff I had at home. Designed it as a "module" for use with other printers as well. Basic brackets for K8200 included. Noticed that I made an 20x20cm plotter as well;-)

Rotate before printing! Be sure that the parts runs smoothly, Grind some pattern of from the printouts and it will move nice. I always drill the holes. the Ballograf pen is 5.75mm and the hole for it is 6mm. Align the holes. Parts needed: "tiny" micro switch (aka form a mouse)
9g Servo
Ballograf pen
5xM2 bolts
2xM2 Nuts
2xM2 Tagged spacers
